{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3388336,"name":"","username":"Jelatinone","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/f475e1/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-18T21:49:32.779Z","cooked":"

Hello All

I am making a robot testbed, with access to the following parts:

  • RoboRIO 1.0
  • CTRE Voltage Regulation Module
  • CTRE Power Distribution Panel
  • NavX
  • OpenMesh Radio
  • Limelight 3
  • 120A Breaker

I want to use this setup as a testbed for vision-based projects, but I want to power it using a typical Type-B wall outlet. Is this possible, and if so how can it be achieved? Please keep in mind I have very much limited electrical experience.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2024-05-18T21:49:59.605Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":224,"reads":587,"readers_count":586,"score":1232.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":466505,"topic_slug":"powering-a-robot-testbed-via-a-typical-wall-outlet","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/powering-frc-test-components-without-a-battery/467481/4","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"Powering FRC test components without a battery","clicks":2}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":58184,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"World's 'Greatest' Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/powering-a-robot-testbed-via-a-typical-wall-outlet/466505/1","custom_user_title":"World's 'Greatest' Programmer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3388339,"name":"Jim Sokoloff","username":"sokoloff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sokoloff/{size}/231724_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-18T21:56:23.366Z","cooked":"

If you want a close simulation for the robot power for no-motor testing, get yourself any 12 volt DC power supply, probably 5A or better, and wire that in in place of the 12V battery.

I used an old computer server power supply, but a PC power supply with have a +12V rail, so if you have an old one of those lying around, you can use it (with a load resistor and tap the green wire to start it. Or, you can use another supply of some sort.

A PC supply is well understood and easy to find, though.

https://www.instructables.com/Convert-an-ATX-Power-Supply-Into-a-Regular-DC-Powe/ has more information if you want to use that route (which I can generally recommend as reasonably easy and reasonably safe for electrical novices to accomplish. (For clarity, you don’t need to do all that drilling and mounting banana posts. You could instead just use the 12V and GND wires and take them straight to an Anderson power connector or to ring terminals and connect to the main breaker.)

Personally, I’d grab something like this. (You can also get a 12V-only like this one, but with some FRC electronics liking slightly higher voltages I’d suggest variable, just so you can use it for individual component testing later.)

Strip wire ends, wrap around terminals, screw terminals down. (Or get your team’s electrical lead to teach you how to crimp terminals to wires, it’s a useful skill.) One end goes to PDP, the other to the power supply. I’m intentionally bypassing the 120A breaker here–you won’t need it with the current being regulated well under that.

Dietz","username":"troy_dietz","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/troy_dietz/{size}/135768_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-18T22:05:45.332Z","cooked":"

As long as you don’t plan on plugging in a motor (or limit yourself to like, a 550 or a BAG), a wall power supply is completely fine. For motor testing, it’s probably easier to put an old battery and charger as the supply, to absorb the inrush and operating current of those motors.

EricH:

You can also get a 12V-only like this one, but with some FRC electronics liking slightly higher voltages I’d suggest variable, just so you can use it for individual component testing later.

On the other hand, while it’s less flexible, a fixed 12V supply carries no risk of harming any 12V components by having the control dials set wrong or turned inadvertently, so there are definitely tradeoffs. I’d lean towards something fixed (or something with a maximum 15V range) for that reason for someone with only the need to bench test 12V components.

This is probably a dumb question, but would turning on the system just require me to literally turn on the Power Supply, and what would happen if I supplied the wrong voltage? (too high or too little)

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2024-05-18T23:03:31.492Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":368,"readers_count":367,"score":78.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":466505,"topic_slug":"powering-a-robot-testbed-via-a-typical-wall-outlet","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":4212,"username":"EricH","name":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":58184,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"World's 'Greatest' Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/powering-a-robot-testbed-via-a-typical-wall-outlet/466505/6","custom_user_title":"World's 'Greatest' Programmer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3388403,"name":"Ankur Raghavan","username":"Ankur-Raghavan","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ankur-raghavan/{size}/207141_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-18T23:15:07.991Z","cooked":"
Jelatinone:

what would happen if I supplied the wrong voltage?

Too high can fry the boards, depending on what they are actually rated for. Some components are rated for higher voltages, but it probably isn’t best to run everything above 12V. Too low shouldn’t be an issue, it just won’t power on. This is similar to if you plugged in a really dead battery.

Jelatinone:

turning on the system just require me to literally turn on the Power Supply

Yes, though at least the first time I would turn the power supply on with the components unplugged to check the voltage/current settings. You could also add a regular robot main breaker in the circuit to act as a power switch.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2024-05-18T23:15:07.991Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":353,"readers_count":352,"score":120.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":466505,"topic_slug":"powering-a-robot-testbed-via-a-typical-wall-outlet","display_username":"Ankur Raghavan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50601,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5⁵-4⁴"},"post_url":"/t/powering-a-robot-testbed-via-a-typical-wall-outlet/466505/7","custom_user_title":"5⁵-4⁴","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3388413,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-18T23:42:42.789Z","cooked":"

Could do something like my model railroad club does. Our main track power supply can easily go over our happy voltage, so the volt knob is taped into position at 15V.

That said, you’d need to make it abundantly clear why it’s taped there and not to move it without setting it back when done. And even then I wouldn’t trust people to not fiddle with it.

The reason I suggested a variable supply is that the battery doesn’t always supply 12V, especially at the end of a match. So as a test, making sure that your system can handle low voltages and still perform adequately will need to be done at some point.

We have a testbed using a power supply similar to the fixed 12V one and have not seen any issue even when running motors off of it. I’d still use a 120A breaker as your on/off switch. We built ours into a mini briefcase to keep it mobile around the shop/comps and easy for people to take home when tinkering. Wiring was not any different than wiring a normal control system, only difference is your battery wires now go to the power supply terminals

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2024-05-19T01:08:10.418Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":274,"readers_count":273,"score":69.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":466505,"topic_slug":"powering-a-robot-testbed-via-a-typical-wall-outlet","display_username":"chrisfl","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":4212,"username":"EricH","name":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":21594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/powering-a-robot-testbed-via-a-typical-wall-outlet/466505/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3388519,"name":"neev dadhania","username":"nevadexehs","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/ecc23a/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-19T04:54:44.293Z","cooked":"

second this, id highly recommend using a PC/server power supply to power it instead of a 12v only supply. pc supplies from reputable brands (seasonic, evga, corsair) tend to be reliable, low chance of exploding, and have good efficiency if you plan to run motors (obviously they must be limited to 5-10a)

last summer, i had our robot plugged in the entire summer with an HP 700w server psu that i had in my basement, it allowed something like 45 amps on the 12v rail, which was enough to run the control system plus motors on limited current to 5a.

there are a handful of ways to approach this, but the easiest & safest way would be to do the following:

image1378×485 50.3 KB

purchase this 12V 10A power supply brick, it wont be enough to run large loads like a motor, but you will be able to run the main control system and multiple co-processors just fine.

That will plug into a generic barrel jack adapter, to simplify plugging it in

For added protection of both the wiring, and power supply, put an inline 10A fuse on the positive supply side heading to the PDP. Some might forgo this, and its not legally necessary by any means, but its a good measure. For the negative wire which is not fused, 16 or 18awg wire would be fine at this level of power.

To finally connect your wires to the PDP, use 1/4" ring crimp terminals, which fit the M6 lugs.

You can also totally follow the suggestions of server power supplies, or ATX power supply modification, but those are a bit more work and require you to be comfortable AND knowledgeable with 120vac. If you want to run motors, 9/10 times just grab a battery.

This might not be the best way of doing it but…
I use a Riden RD6006 adjustable bench power supply to power my test rig, connected via alligator clips…

5001716948769_.pic1280×1707 207 KB

My test bench includes

  • roboRIO 1.0
  • CTRE PDP
  • CTRE VRM
  • CTRE CANIvore
  • CTRE Pigeon 2.0
  • navX2
  • 12V to 5V module (for Jetson)
  • Jetson Nano 4G
  • Radio (Vivid Hosting or custom home radio)
  • REV servo power module
  • 2x VEX 888
  • 1x USB camera (conected to Jetson)

(and when necessary)
VEX claw bot consist of…

  • 2x VEX 393 motor hooked up to VEX motor controller 29 powered via REV Servo power module
  • 2x VEX 393 motor hooked up to VEX 888 (this is not FRC legal for an actual competition)
  • Limit switch for the arm
  • VEX optical encoder for both chassis wheel
  • Potentiometer as analog encoder for the arm
    5021716948879_.pic1280×1707 261 KB

This clawbot would connect to my test bench via a umbilical cord as there’s no way to fit anything on the clawbot.

I have mostly no issue running the whole test bench under 14V 6A setting for the power supply if there’s no robot attached. Typically only 2.5A max is drown (jetson running under full load). Only when VEX chassis motor is breaking suddenly would the roborio be blackout briefly but I don’t even need to run it that fast.
